Award.AwardTitle: Intracellular metal pumping in microbial excavation by microbes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyanobacteria are among the most common, widespread and environmentally significant agents of bio-erosion, boring microscopic galleries as they grow within carbonate substrates. The mechanisms by which they achieve this against chemical equilibrium are poorly known. Our work showed that boring is likely driven by the action of membrane-bound Ca2+ transporting ATPases, powered directly by photosynthetically derived ATP, acting to maintain the levels of free Ca2+ in the interstitial space of the distal borehole very low, a situation that promotes local calcite dissolution, with Ca2+ then travelling intra-cellularly down a concentration gradient in the filament to be released into the outside medium. We intend here to advance our understanding of the boring mechanism at the molecular, genetic and cellular level and to test its universality, by probing its variability in essence or detail with respect to microbial agents other than the models previously used, and for mineral substrates other than CaCO3. We will achieve this through genetic and cellular characterization of the Ca2+ transport systems, molecular biology techniques and micro-imaging techniques based on confocal microscopy of model microbes. We will also interrogate natural complex communities of boring microorganims from a variety of geographic and mineralogical settings (limestones, dolostones and biogenic carbonates) for their compliance with the Ca2+-transport mechanism. Finally, renewed efforts of cultivation will be used to address the mysterious excavation of phosphates, dolomite, and magnesite, a capacity that model microbes lacks, but is assumed to take place in nature.

Moving from descriptive to mechanistic models of understanding, as this work will attempt, remains one of the frontiers of geobiology. The research will attempt to ascertain the exact mechanisms by which microbes can use the energy from the sun to power dissolving minerals like limestone, when geochemistry would predict they should not dissolve at all. This knowledge would offer the potential to explain several biological and geological phenomena of widespread importance. For example, it will involve the study of physiology of calcium transport, the same phenomenon that drives muscle movement in humans, in a very different setting. It may also contribute to our ability to predict the consequences of global acidification of the oceans with respect to coastal limestone dissolution. It will contribute basic knowledge with potential applications in biomaterial science, potentially even providing a means for combating calcification in engineered systems, or for deterring the bio-deterioration of buildings and monuments. The research will be intricately embedded with activities in education, training, dissemination and outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied how some photosynthetic microorganisms are able to bore and grow into solid carbonate rocks like limestones, dolomites and corals, even when chemistry would predict that this is not possible. In nature, this constitues an important phenomenon known as bioerosion.

Our studies revealed that such microorganisms have developed unusual adaptations to accomplish this. They are able to take up calcium from the mineral, which they transport inside their cells, to be released at the solid suface. This is accomplished by the coordinated placement of calcium transport machinery so that all cells transport in the same direction; additionally,  they differentiate specialized cells, calcicytes, that regulate calcium traffic by acting as depots.To compensate for electrical charge, cells countertransport protons towards the areas of the solid that are being dissolved.  These are indeed elegant adaptations to circumvent the apparent geochemical paradox of carbonate dissolution by phototrophs, particularly in marine systems that are saturated for calcium carbonate minerals. Unexpectedly, we could also demonstrate that these organisms can convert the carbonate ions released by dissolution into organic matter, constituting the only living beings known to use carbonate carbon for growth. All of these reactions are powered by light energy. Genetic analyses of model organisms in the lab have shown that adaptations to living inside the rock involve a large array of genes, many of yet unknwon function, that we plan to study in the future.

In nature, these rock-inhabiting organisms come in communities the composition of which is quite complex and is dependent on the composition of the rock substrate and on the geographic location. We discovered a new group of microorganisms, anoxygenic phototrophs, that may be involved in the dissolution process and that was hitherto not associated with the bioerosive phenomenon, which we plan to study further in the future.

In terms of broader impacts, graduate students E.Ramirez-Reinat (Ph.D, 2012, now at GC University) and B. Guida (Ph.D, 2016, now at U.Arizona), both Hispanic, as well as D.Roush (continuing) have been trained, as has one undergraduate (B. Bennett, now at Haliae Biofuels), and one postdoc (E. Couradeau; now at U Burgundy). We set up a website, participated in curriculum development workshops for local charter school biology teachers (2014), helped with the Mesa HS Biotech Academy (2012, 2014, 2015), and contributed STEM curriculum weakly in 2014 to STEAM Machines with 6th graders in the Buckeye, AZ, SD. The PI gave several invited seminars on the topic. Students presented at many international, national and local venues (ISPP-2015; ASM-2011; AGU-2015), some recieving prizes. We organized a session on carbonates and microbes at the Fall 15 AGU, and an international workshop on cyanobacteria at ASU
